F0001.name: fatal
F0001.description: Used when an error occurred preventing the analysis of a               module (unable to find it for instance).

F0002.name: astroid-error
F0002.description: Used when an unexpected error occurred while building the Astroid  representation. This is usually accompanied by a traceback. Please report such errors !

F0010.name: parse-error
F0010.description: Used when an exception occurred while building the Astroid representation which could be handled by astroid.

F0011.name: config-parse-error
F0011.description: Used when an exception occurred while parsing a pylint configuration file.

F0202.name: method-check-failed
F0202.description: Used when Pylint has been unable to check methods signature compatibility for an unexpected reason. Please report this kind if you don't make sense of it.

E0001.name: syntax-error
E0001.description: Used when a syntax error is raised for a module.

E0011.name: unrecognized-inline-option
E0011.description: Used when an unknown inline option is encountered.

E0013.name: bad-plugin-value
E0013.message: Plugin '%s' is impossible to load, is it installed ? ('%s')
E0013.description: Used when a bad value is used in 'load-plugins'.

E0014.name: bad-configuration-section
E0014.message: Out-of-place setting encountered in top level configuration-section '%s' : '%s'
E0014.description: Used when we detect a setting in the top level of a toml configuration that shouldn't be there.

E0015.name: unrecognized-option
E0015.description: Used when we detect an option that we do not recognize.

E1700.name: yield-inside-async-function
E1700.description: Used when an `yield` or `yield from` statement is found inside an async function.

E1701.name: not-async-context-manager
E1701.message: Async context manager '%s' doesn't implement __aenter__ and __aexit__.
E1701.description: Used when an async context manager is used with an object that does not implement the async context management protocol.

E0111.name: bad-reversed-sequence
E0111.message: The first reversed() argument is not a sequence
E0111.description: Used when the first argument to reversed() builtin isn't a sequence (does not implement __reversed__, nor __getitem__ and __len__

E0119.name: misplaced-format-function
E0119.message: format function is not called on str
E0119.description: Emitted when format function is not called on str object. e.g doing print("value: {}").format(123) instead of print("value: {}".format(123)). This might not be what the user intended to do.

E0100.name: init-is-generator
E0100.description: Used when the special class method __init__ is turned into a generator by a yield in its body.

E0101.name: return-in-init
E0101.description: Used when the special class method __init__ has an explicit return value.

E0102.name: function-redefined
E0102.description: Used when a function / class / method is redefined.

E0103.name: not-in-loop
E0103.description: Used when break or continue keywords are used outside a loop.

E0104.name: return-outside-function
E0104.description: Used when a "return" statement is found outside a function or method.

E0105.name: yield-outside-function
E0105.description: Used when a "yield" statement is found outside a function or method.

E0106.name: return-arg-in-generator
E0106.description: Used when a "return" statement with an argument is found outside in a generator function or method (e.g. with some "yield" statements).

E0107.name: nonexistent-operator
E0107.description: Used when you attempt to use the C-style pre-increment or pre-decrement operator -- and ++, which doesn't exist in Python.

E0108.name: duplicate-argument-name
E0108.message: Duplicate argument name %s in function definition
E0108.description: Duplicate argument names in function definitions are syntax errors.

E0110.name: abstract-class-instantiated
E0110.message: Abstract class %r with abstract methods instantiated
E0110.description: Used when an abstract class with `abc.ABCMeta` as metaclass has abstract methods and is instantiated.

E0112.name: too-many-star-expressions
E0112.message: More than one starred expression in assignment
E0112.description: Emitted when there are more than one starred expressions (`*x`) in an assignment. This is a SyntaxError.

E0113.name: invalid-star-assignment-target
E0113.message: Starred assignment target must be in a list or tuple
E0113.description: Emitted when a star expression is used as a starred assignment target.

E0114.name: star-needs-assignment-target
E0114.message: Can use starred expression only in assignment target
E0114.description: Emitted when a star expression is not used in an assignment target.

E0115.name: nonlocal-and-global
E0115.description: Emitted when a name is both nonlocal and global.

E0116.name: continue-in-finally
E0116.description: Emitted when the `continue` keyword is found inside a finally clause, which is a SyntaxError.

E0117.name: nonlocal-without-binding
E0117.description: Emitted when a nonlocal variable does not have an attached name somewhere in the parent scopes

E0118.name: used-prior-global-declaration
E0118.message: Name %r is used prior to global declaration
E0118.description: Emitted when a name is used prior a global declaration, which results in an error since Python 3.6.

E0301.name: non-iterator-returned
E0301.description: Used when an __iter__ method returns something which is not an iterable (i.e. has no `__next__` method)

E0302.name: unexpected-special-method-signature
E0302.message: The special method %r expects %s param(s), %d %s given
E0302.description: Emitted when a special method was defined with an invalid number of parameters. If it has too few or too many, it might not work at all.

E0303.name: invalid-length-returned
E0303.description: Used when a __len__ method returns something which is not a non-negative integer

E0304.name: invalid-bool-returned
E0304.description: Used when a __bool__ method returns something which is not a bool

E0305.name: invalid-index-returned
E0305.description: Used when an __index__ method returns something which is not an integer

E0306.name: invalid-repr-returned
E0306.description: Used when a __repr__ method returns something which is not a string

E0307.name: invalid-str-returned
E0307.description: Used when a __str__ method returns something which is not a string

E0308.name: invalid-bytes-returned
E0308.description: Used when a __bytes__ method returns something which is not bytes

E0309.name: invalid-hash-returned
E0309.description: Used when a __hash__ method returns something which is not an integer

E0310.name: invalid-length-hint-returned
E0310.description: Used when a __length_hint__ method returns something which is not a non-negative integer

E0311.name: invalid-format-returned
E0311.description: Used when a __format__ method returns something which is not a string

E0312.name: invalid-getnewargs-returned
E0312.description: Used when a __getnewargs__ method returns something which is not a tuple

E0313.name: invalid-getnewargs-ex-returned
E0313.message: __getnewargs_ex__ does not return a tuple containing (tuple, dict)
E0313.description: Used when a __getnewargs_ex__ method returns something which is not of the form tuple(tuple, dict)

E0202.name: method-hidden
E0202.message: An attribute defined in %s line %s hides this method
E0202.description: Used when a class defines a method which is hidden by an instance attribute from an ancestor class or set by some client code.

E0203.name: access-member-before-definition
E0203.message: Access to member %r before its definition line %s
E0203.description: Used when an instance member is accessed before it's actually assigned.

E0211.name: no-method-argument
E0211.description: Used when a method which should have the bound instance as first argument has no argument defined.

E0213.name: no-self-argument
E0213.message: Method %r should have "self" as first argument
E0213.description: Used when a method has an attribute different the "self" as first argument. This is considered as an error since this is a so common convention that you shouldn't break it!

E0236.name: invalid-slots-object
E0236.message: Invalid object %r in __slots__, must contain only non empty strings
E0236.description: Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __slots__.

E0237.name: assigning-non-slot
E0237.message: Assigning to attribute %r not defined in class slots
E0237.description: Used when assigning to an attribute not defined in the class slots.

E0238.name: invalid-slots
E0238.description: Used when an invalid __slots__ is found in class. Only a string, an iterable or a sequence is permitted.

E0239.name: inherit-non-class
E0239.message: Inheriting %r, which is not a class.
E0239.description: Used when a class inherits from something which is not a class.

E0240.name: inconsistent-mro
E0240.message: Inconsistent method resolution order for class %r
E0240.description: Used when a class has an inconsistent method resolution order.

E0241.name: duplicate-bases
E0241.description: Duplicate use of base classes in derived classes raise TypeErrors.

E0242.name: class-variable-slots-conflict
E0242.message: Value %r in slots conflicts with class variable
E0242.description: Used when a value in __slots__ conflicts with a class variable, property or method.

E0243.name: invalid-class-object
E0243.message: Invalid assignment to '__class__'. Should be a class definition but got a '%s'
E0243.description: Used when an invalid object is assigned to a __class__ property. Only a class is permitted.

E0244.name: invalid-enum-extension
E0244.description: Used when a class tries to extend an inherited Enum class. Doing so will raise a TypeError at runtime.

E3701.name: invalid-field-call
E3701.description: The dataclasses.field() specifier should only be used as the value of an assignment within a dataclass, or within the make_dataclass() function.

E0401.name: import-error
E0401.description: Used when pylint has been unable to import a module.

E0402.name: relative-beyond-top-level
E0402.message: Attempted relative import beyond top-level package
E0402.description: Used when a relative import tries to access too many levels in the current package.

E0701.name: bad-except-order
E0701.description: Used when except clauses are not in the correct order (from the more specific to the more generic). If you don't fix the order, some exceptions may not be caught by the most specific handler.

E0702.name: raising-bad-type
E0702.message: Raising %s while only classes or instances are allowed
E0702.description: Used when something which is neither a class nor an instance is raised (i.e. a `TypeError` will be raised).

E0704.name: misplaced-bare-raise
E0704.message: The raise statement is not inside an except clause
E0704.description: Used when a bare raise is not used inside an except clause. This generates an error, since there are no active exceptions to be reraised. An exception to this rule is represented by a bare raise inside a finally clause, which might work, as long as an exception is raised inside the try block, but it is nevertheless a code smell that must not be relied upon.

E0705.name: bad-exception-cause
E0705.message: Exception cause set to something which is not an exception, nor None
E0705.description: Used when using the syntax "raise ... from ...", where the exception cause is not an exception, nor None.

E0710.name: raising-non-exception
E0710.message: Raising a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException
E0710.description: Used when a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException is raised.

E0711.name: notimplemented-raised
E0711.description: Used when NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError

E0712.name: catching-non-exception
E0712.message: Catching an exception which doesn't inherit from Exception: %s
E0712.description: Used when a class which doesn't inherit from Exception is used as an exception in an except clause.

E1200.name: logging-unsupported-format
E1200.message: Unsupported logging format character %r (%#02x) at index %d
E1200.description: Used when an unsupported format character is used in a logging statement format string.

E1201.name: logging-format-truncated
E1201.message: Logging format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
E1201.description: Used when a logging statement format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.

E1205.name: logging-too-many-args
E1205.message: Too many arguments for logging format string
E1205.description: Used when a logging format string is given too many arguments.

E1206.name: logging-too-few-args
E1206.message: Not enough arguments for logging format string
E1206.description: Used when a logging format string is given too few arguments.

E3102.name: positional-only-arguments-expected
E3102.message: `%s()` got some positional-only arguments passed as keyword arguments: %s
E3102.description: Emitted when positional-only arguments have been passed as keyword arguments. Remove the keywords for the affected arguments in the function call.

E4702.name: modified-iterating-dict
E4702.message: Iterated dict '%s' is being modified inside for loop body, iterate through a copy of it instead.
E4702.description: Emitted when items are added or removed to a dict being iterated through. Doing so raises a RuntimeError.

E4703.name: modified-iterating-set
E4703.message: Iterated set '%s' is being modified inside for loop body, iterate through a copy of it instead.
E4703.description: Emitted when items are added or removed to a set being iterated through. Doing so raises a RuntimeError.

E1003.name: bad-super-call
E1003.message: Bad first argument %r given to super()
E1003.description: Used when another argument than the current class is given as first argument of the super builtin.

E1507.name: invalid-envvar-value
E1507.description: Env manipulation functions support only string type arguments. See https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.getenv.

E1519.name: singledispatch-method
E1519.message: singledispatch decorator should not be used with methods, use singledispatchmethod instead.
E1519.description: singledispatch should decorate functions and not class/instance methods. Use singledispatchmethod for those cases.

E1520.name: singledispatchmethod-function
E1520.message: singledispatchmethod decorator should not be used with functions, use singledispatch instead.
E1520.description: singledispatchmethod should decorate class/instance methods and not functions. Use singledispatch for those cases.

E1300.name: bad-format-character
E1300.description: Used when an unsupported format character is used in a format string.

E1301.name: truncated-format-string
E1301.message: Format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
E1301.description: Used when a format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.

E1302.name: mixed-format-string
E1302.message: Mixing named and unnamed conversion specifiers in format string
E1302.description: Used when a format string contains both named (e.g. '%(foo)d') and unnamed (e.g. '%d') conversion specifiers.  This is also used when a named conversion specifier contains * for the minimum field width and/or precision.

E1303.name: format-needs-mapping
E1303.message: Expected mapping for format string, not %s
E1303.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with an argument that is not a mapping.

E1304.name: missing-format-string-key
E1304.message: Missing key %r in format string dictionary
E1304.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that doesn't contain all the keys required by the format string.

E1305.name: too-many-format-args
E1305.message: Too many arguments for format string
E1305.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too many arguments.

E1306.name: too-few-format-args
E1306.message: Not enough arguments for format string
E1306.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too few arguments

E1307.name: bad-string-format-type
E1307.message: Argument %r does not match format type %r
E1307.description: Used when a type required by format string is not suitable for actual argument type

E1310.name: bad-str-strip-call
E1310.description: The argument to a str.{l,r,}strip call contains a duplicate character,

E1133.name: not-an-iterable
E1133.message: Non-iterable value %s is used in an iterating context
E1133.description: Used when a non-iterable value is used in place where iterable is expected

E1134.name: not-a-mapping
E1134.message: Non-mapping value %s is used in a mapping context
E1134.description: Used when a non-mapping value is used in place where mapping is expected

E1101.name: no-member
E1101.description: Used when a variable is accessed for a nonexistent member.

E1102.name: not-callable
E1102.description: Used when an object being called has been inferred to a non callable object.

E1111.name: assignment-from-no-return
E1111.message: Assigning result of a function call, where the function has no return
E1111.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function doesn't return anything.

E1120.name: no-value-for-parameter
E1120.message: No value for argument %s in %s call
E1120.description: Used when a function call passes too few arguments.

E1121.name: too-many-function-args
E1121.message: Too many positional arguments for %s call
E1121.description: Used when a function call passes too many positional arguments.

E1123.name: unexpected-keyword-arg
E1123.description: Used when a function call passes a keyword argument that doesn't correspond to one of the function's parameter names.

E1124.name: redundant-keyword-arg
E1124.message: Argument %r passed by position and keyword in %s call
E1124.description: Used when a function call would result in assigning multiple values to a function parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from a keyword argument.

E1125.name: missing-kwoa
E1125.message: Missing mandatory keyword argument %r in %s call
E1125.description: Used when a function call does not pass a mandatory keyword-only argument.

E1126.name: invalid-sequence-index
E1126.message: Sequence index is not an int, slice, or instance with __index__
E1126.description: Used when a sequence type is indexed with an invalid type. Valid types are ints, slices, and objects with an __index__ method.

E1127.name: invalid-slice-index
E1127.message: Slice index is not an int, None, or instance with __index__
E1127.description: Used when a slice index is not an integer, None, or an object with an __index__ method.

E1128.name: assignment-from-none
E1128.message: Assigning result of a function call, where the function returns None
E1128.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function returns nothing but None.

E1129.name: not-context-manager
E1129.description: Used when an instance in a with statement doesn't implement the context manager protocol(__enter__/__exit__).

E1130.name: invalid-unary-operand-type
E1130.description: Emitted when a unary operand is used on an object which does not support this type of operation.

E1131.name: unsupported-binary-operation
E1131.description: Emitted when a binary arithmetic operation between two operands is not supported.

E1132.name: repeated-keyword
E1132.message: Got multiple values for keyword argument %r in function call
E1132.description: Emitted when a function call got multiple values for a keyword.

E1135.name: unsupported-membership-test
E1135.description: Emitted when an instance in membership test expression doesn't implement membership protocol (__contains__/__iter__/__getitem__).

E1136.name: unsubscriptable-object
E1136.description: Emitted when a subscripted value doesn't support subscription (i.e. doesn't define __getitem__ method or __class_getitem__ for a class).

E1137.name: unsupported-assignment-operation
E1137.description: Emitted when an object does not support item assignment (i.e. doesn't define __setitem__ method).

E1138.name: unsupported-delete-operation
E1138.description: Emitted when an object does not support item deletion (i.e. doesn't define __delitem__ method).

E1139.name: invalid-metaclass
E1139.description: Emitted whenever we can detect that a class is using, as a metaclass, something which might be invalid for using as a metaclass.

E1141.name: dict-iter-missing-items
E1141.message: Unpacking a dictionary in iteration without calling .items()
E1141.description: Emitted when trying to iterate through a dict without calling .items()

E1142.name: await-outside-async
E1142.message: 'await' should be used within an async function
E1142.description: Emitted when await is used outside an async function.

E1143.name: unhashable-member
E1143.message: '%s' is unhashable and can't be used as a %s in a %s
E1143.description: Emitted when a dict key or set member is not hashable (i.e. doesn't define __hash__ method).

E1144.name: invalid-slice-step
E1144.description: Used when a slice step is 0 and the object doesn't implement a custom __getitem__ method.

E6004.name: broken-noreturn
E6004.message: 'NoReturn' inside compound types is broken in 3.7.0 / 3.7.1
E6004.description: ``typing.NoReturn`` inside compound types is broken in Python 3.7.0 and 3.7.1. If not dependent on runtime introspection, use string annotation instead. E.g. ``Callable[..., 'NoReturn']``. https://bugs.python.org/issue34921

E6005.name: broken-collections-callable
E6005.message: 'collections.abc.Callable' inside Optional and Union is broken in 3.9.0 / 3.9.1 (use 'typing.Callable' instead)
E6005.description: ``collections.abc.Callable`` inside Optional and Union is broken in Python 3.9.0 and 3.9.1. Use ``typing.Callable`` for these cases instead. https://bugs.python.org/issue42965

E2501.name: invalid-unicode-codec
E2501.message: UTF-16 and UTF-32 aren't backward compatible. Use UTF-8 instead
E2501.description: For compatibility use UTF-8 instead of UTF-16/UTF-32. See also https://bugs.python.org/issue1503789 for a history of this issue. And https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/102205/ for some possible problems when using UTF-16 for instance.

E2502.name: bidirectional-unicode
E2502.message: Contains control characters that can permit obfuscated code executed differently than displayed
E2502.description:
bidirectional unicode are typically not displayed characters required to display right-to-left (RTL) script (i.e. Chinese, Japanese, Arabic, Hebrew, ...) correctly. So can you trust this code? Are you sure it displayed correctly in all editors? If you did not write it or your language is not RTL, remove the special characters, as they could be used to trick you into executing code, that does something else than what it looks like.
More Information:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidirectional_text
https://trojansource.codes/

E2510.name: invalid-character-backspace
E2510.message: Invalid unescaped character backspace, use "\b" instead.
E2510.description: Moves the cursor back, so the character after it will overwrite the character before.

E2511.name: invalid-character-carriage-return
E2511.message: Invalid unescaped character carriage-return, use "\r" instead.
E2511.description: Moves the cursor to the start of line, subsequent characters overwrite the start of the line.

E2512.name: invalid-character-sub
E2512.message: Invalid unescaped character sub, use "\x1A" instead.
E2512.description: Ctrl+Z "End of text" on Windows. Some programs (such as type) ignore the rest of the file after it.

E2513.name: invalid-character-esc
E2513.message: Invalid unescaped character esc, use "\x1B" instead.
E2513.description: Commonly initiates escape codes which allow arbitrary control of the terminal.

E2514.name: invalid-character-nul
E2514.message: Invalid unescaped character nul, use "\0" instead.
E2514.description: Mostly end of input for python.

E2515.name: invalid-character-zero-width-space
E2515.message: Invalid unescaped character zero-width-space, use "\u200B" instead.
E2515.description: Invisible space character could hide real code execution.

E0601.name: used-before-assignment
E0601.description: Emitted when a local variable is accessed before its assignment took place. Assignments in try blocks are assumed not to have occurred when evaluating associated except/finally blocks. Assignments in except blocks are assumed not to have occurred when evaluating statements outside the block, except when the associated try block contains a return statement.

E0602.name: undefined-variable
E0602.description: Used when an undefined variable is accessed.

E0603.name: undefined-all-variable
E0603.description: Used when an undefined variable name is referenced in __all__.

E0604.name: invalid-all-object
E0604.message: Invalid object %r in __all__, must contain only strings
E0604.description: Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __all__.

E0605.name: invalid-all-format
E0605.message: Invalid format for __all__, must be tuple or list
E0605.description: Used when __all__ has an invalid format.

E0611.name: no-name-in-module
E0611.description: Used when a name cannot be found in a module.

E0633.name: unpacking-non-sequence
E0633.description: Used when something which is not a sequence is used in an unpack assignment

E0643.name: potential-index-error
E0643.description: Emitted when an index used on an iterable goes beyond the length of that iterable.

W0012.name: unknown-option-value
W0012.message: Unknown option value for '%s', expected a valid pylint message and got '%s'
W0012.description: Used when an unknown value is encountered for an option.

W3601.name: bad-chained-comparison
W3601.message: Suspicious %s-part chained comparison using semantically incompatible operators (%s)
W3601.description: Used when there is a chained comparison where one expression is part of two comparisons that belong to different semantic groups ("<" does not mean the same thing as "is", chaining them in "0 < x is None" is probably a mistake).

W0143.name: comparison-with-callable
W0143.message: Comparing against a callable, did you omit the parenthesis?
W0143.description: This message is emitted when pylint detects that a comparison with a callable was made, which might suggest that some parenthesis were omitted, resulting in potential unwanted behaviour.

W0177.name: nan-comparison
W0177.description: Used when an expression is compared to NaN values like numpy.NaN and float('nan').

W0107.name: unnecessary-pass
W0107.description: Used when a "pass" statement that can be avoided is encountered.

W0101.name: unreachable
W0101.description: Used when there is some code behind a "return" or "raise" statement, which will never be accessed.

W0102.name: dangerous-default-value
W0102.description: Used when a mutable value as list or dictionary is detected in a default value for an argument.

W0104.name: pointless-statement
W0104.message: Statement seems to have no effect
W0104.description: Used when a statement doesn't have (or at least seems to) any effect.

W0105.name: pointless-string-statement
W0105.description: Used when a string is used as a statement (which of course has no effect). This is a particular case of W0104 with its own message so you can easily disable it if you're using those strings as documentation, instead of comments.

W0106.name: expression-not-assigned
W0106.description: Used when an expression that is not a function call is assigned to nothing. Probably something else was intended.

W0108.name: unnecessary-lambda
W0108.description: Used when the body of a lambda expression is a function call on the same argument list as the lambda itself; such lambda expressions are in all but a few cases replaceable with the function being called in the body of the lambda.

W0109.name: duplicate-key
W0109.description: Used when a dictionary expression binds the same key multiple times.

W0122.name: exec-used
W0122.description: Raised when the 'exec' statement is used. It's dangerous to use this function for a user input, and it's also slower than actual code in general. This doesn't mean you should never use it, but you should consider alternatives first and restrict the functions available.

W0123.name: eval-used
W0123.description: Used when you use the "eval" function, to discourage its usage. Consider using `ast.literal_eval` for safely evaluating strings containing Python expressions from untrusted sources.

W0124.name: confusing-with-statement
W0124.message: Following "as" with another context manager looks like a tuple.
W0124.description: Emitted when a `with` statement component returns multiple values and uses name binding with `as` only for a part of those values, as in with ctx() as a, b. This can be misleading, since it's not clear if the context manager returns a tuple or if the node without a name binding is another context manager.

W0125.name: using-constant-test
W0125.message: Using a conditional statement with a constant value
W0125.description: Emitted when a conditional statement (If or ternary if) uses a constant value for its test. This might not be what the user intended to do.

W0126.name: missing-parentheses-for-call-in-test
W0126.message: Using a conditional statement with potentially wrong function or method call due to missing parentheses
W0126.description: Emitted when a conditional statement (If or ternary if) seems to wrongly call a function due to missing parentheses

W0127.name: self-assigning-variable
W0127.message: Assigning the same variable %r to itself
W0127.description: Emitted when we detect that a variable is assigned to itself

W0128.name: redeclared-assigned-name
W0128.description: Emitted when we detect that a variable was redeclared in the same assignment.

W0129.name: assert-on-string-literal
W0129.message: Assert statement has a string literal as its first argument. The assert will %s fail.
W0129.description: Used when an assert statement has a string literal as its first argument, which will cause the assert to always pass.

W0130.name: duplicate-value
W0130.description: This message is emitted when a set contains the same value two or more times.

W0131.name: named-expr-without-context
W0131.description: Emitted if named expression is used to do a regular assignment outside a context like if, for, while, or a comprehension.

W0133.name: pointless-exception-statement
W0133.description: Used when an exception is created without being assigned, raised or returned for subsequent use elsewhere.

W0134.name: return-in-finally
W0134.description: Emitted when a 'return' statement is found in a 'finally' block. This will overwrite the return value of a function and should be avoided.

W0150.name: lost-exception
W0150.message: %s statement in finally block may swallow exception
W0150.description: Used when a break or a return statement is found inside the finally clause of a try...finally block: the exceptions raised in the try clause will be silently swallowed instead of being re-raised.

W0199.name: assert-on-tuple
W0199.message: Assert called on a populated tuple. Did you mean 'assert x,y'?
W0199.description: A call of assert on a tuple will always evaluate to true if the tuple is not empty, and will always evaluate to false if it is.

W0120.name: useless-else-on-loop
W0120.message: Else clause on loop without a break statement, remove the else and de-indent all the code inside it
W0120.description: Loops should only have an else clause if they can exit early with a break statement, otherwise the statements under else should be on the same scope as the loop itself.

W0717.name: too-many-try-statements
W0717.description: Try clause contains too many statements.

W0201.name: attribute-defined-outside-init
W0201.description: Used when an instance attribute is defined outside the __init__ method.

W0211.name: bad-staticmethod-argument
W0211.message: Static method with %r as first argument
W0211.description: Used when a static method has "self" or a value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option or valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option as first argument.

W0212.name: protected-access
W0212.message: Access to a protected member %s of a client class
W0212.description: Used when a protected member (i.e. class member with a name beginning with an underscore) is access outside the class or a descendant of the class where it's defined.

W0213.name: implicit-flag-alias
W0213.message: Flag member %(overlap)s shares bit positions with %(sources)s
W0213.description: Used when multiple integer values declared within an enum.IntFlag class share a common bit position.

W0221.name: arguments-differ
W0221.description: Used when a method has a different number of arguments than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method. Extra arguments with default values are ignored.

W0222.name: signature-differs
W0222.description: Used when a method signature is different than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.

W0223.name: abstract-method
W0223.message: Method %r is abstract in class %r but is not overridden in child class %r
W0223.description: Used when an abstract method (i.e. raise NotImplementedError) is not overridden in concrete class.

W0231.name: super-init-not-called
W0231.message: __init__ method from base class %r is not called
W0231.description: Used when an ancestor class method has an __init__ method which is not called by a derived class.

W0233.name: non-parent-init-called
W0233.message: __init__ method from a non direct base class %r is called
W0233.description: Used when an __init__ method is called on a class which is not in the direct ancestors for the analysed class.

W0236.name: invalid-overridden-method
W0236.message: Method %r was expected to be %r, found it instead as %r
W0236.description: Used when we detect that a method was overridden in a way that does not match its base class which could result in potential bugs at runtime.

W0237.name: arguments-renamed
W0237.description: Used when a method parameter has a different name than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.

W0238.name: unused-private-member
W0238.description: Emitted when a private member of a class is defined but not used.

W0239.name: overridden-final-method
W0239.message: Method %r overrides a method decorated with typing.final which is defined in class %r
W0239.description: Used when a method decorated with typing.final has been overridden.

W0240.name: subclassed-final-class
W0240.message: Class %r is a subclass of a class decorated with typing.final: %r
W0240.description: Used when a class decorated with typing.final has been subclassed.

W0244.name: redefined-slots-in-subclass
W0244.description: Used when a slot is re-defined in a subclass.

W0245.name: super-without-brackets
W0245.description: Used when a call to super does not have brackets and thus is not an actual call and does not work as expected.

W0246.name: useless-parent-delegation
W0246.message: Useless parent or super() delegation in method %r
W0246.description: Used whenever we can detect that an overridden method is useless, relying on parent or super() delegation to do the same thing as another method from the MRO.

W0160.name: consider-ternary-expression
W0160.message: Consider rewriting as a ternary expression
W0160.description: Multiple assign statements spread across if/else blocks can be rewritten with a single assignment and ternary expression

W0141.name: bad-builtin
W0141.description: Used when a disallowed builtin function is used (see the bad-function option). Usual disallowed functions are the ones like map, or filter , where Python offers now some cleaner alternative like list comprehension.

W3201.name: bad-dunder-name
W3201.message: Bad or misspelled dunder method name %s.
W3201.description: Used when a dunder method is misspelled or defined with a name not within the predefined list of dunder names.

W1641.name: eq-without-hash
W1641.description: Used when a class implements __eq__ but not __hash__. Objects get None as their default __hash__ implementation if they also implement __eq__.

W0401.name: wildcard-import
W0401.description: Used when `from module import *` is detected.

W0404.name: reimported
W0404.description: Used when a module is imported more than once.

W0406.name: import-self
W0406.description: Used when a module is importing itself.

W0407.name: preferred-module
W0407.description: Used when a module imported has a preferred replacement module.

W0410.name: misplaced-future
W0410.message: __future__ import is not the first non docstring statement
W0410.description: Python 2.5 and greater require __future__ import to be the first non docstring statement in the module.

W0416.name: shadowed-import
W0416.description: Used when a module is aliased with a name that shadows another import.

W4901.name: deprecated-module
W4901.description: A module marked as deprecated is imported.

W0702.name: bare-except
W0702.description: A bare ``except:`` clause will catch ``SystemExit`` and ``KeyboardInterrupt`` exceptions, making it harder to interrupt a program with ``Control-C``, and can disguise other problems. If you want to catch all exceptions that signal program errors, use ``except Exception:`` (bare except is equivalent to ``except BaseException:``).

W0705.name: duplicate-except
W0705.description: Used when an except catches a type that was already caught by a previous handler.

W0706.name: try-except-raise
W0706.description: Used when an except handler uses raise as its first or only operator. This is useless because it raises back the exception immediately. Remove the raise operator or the entire try-except-raise block!

W0707.name: raise-missing-from
W0707.description: Python's exception chaining shows the traceback of the current exception, but also of the original exception. When you raise a new exception after another exception was caught it's likely that the second exception is a friendly re-wrapping of the first exception. In such cases `raise from` provides a better link between the two tracebacks in the final error.

W0711.name: binary-op-exception
W0711.message: Exception to catch is the result of a binary "%s" operation
W0711.description: Used when the exception to catch is of the form "except A or B:".  If intending to catch multiple, rewrite as "except (A, B):"

W0715.name: raising-format-tuple
W0715.message: Exception arguments suggest string formatting might be intended
W0715.description: Used when passing multiple arguments to an exception constructor, the first of them a string literal containing what appears to be placeholders intended for formatting

W0716.name: wrong-exception-operation
W0716.description: Used when an operation is done against an exception, but the operation is not valid for the exception in question. Usually emitted when having binary operations between exceptions in except handlers.

W0718.name: broad-exception-caught
W0718.description: If you use a naked ``except Exception:`` clause, you might end up catching exceptions other than the ones you expect to catch. This can hide bugs or make it harder to debug programs when unrelated errors are hidden.

W0719.name: broad-exception-raised
W0719.description: Raising exceptions that are too generic force you to catch exceptions generically too. It will force you to use a naked ``except Exception:`` clause. You might then end up catching exceptions other than the ones you expect to catch. This can hide bugs or make it harder to debug programs when unrelated errors are hidden.

W0301.name: unnecessary-semicolon
W0301.description: Used when a statement is ended by a semi-colon (";"), which isn't necessary (that's python, not C ;).

W0311.name: bad-indentation
W0311.description: Used when an unexpected number of indentation's tabulations or spaces has been found.

W1201.name: logging-not-lazy
W1201.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<logging method>(format_string % (format_args...))". Use another type of string formatting instead. You can use % formatting but leave interpolation to the logging function by passing the parameters as arguments. If logging-fstring-interpolation is disabled then you can use fstring formatting. If logging-format-interpolation is disabled then you can use str.format.

W1202.name: logging-format-interpolation
W1202.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<logging method>(format_string.format(format_args...))". Use another type of string formatting instead. You can use % formatting but leave interpolation to the logging function by passing the parameters as arguments. If logging-fstring-interpolation is disabled then you can use fstring formatting. If logging-not-lazy is disabled then you can use % formatting as normal.

W1203.name: logging-fstring-interpolation
W1203.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<logging method>(f"...")".Use another type of string formatting instead. You can use % formatting but leave interpolation to the logging function by passing the parameters as arguments. If logging-format-interpolation is disabled then you can use str.format. If logging-not-lazy is disabled then you can use % formatting as normal.

W3101.name: missing-timeout
W3101.message: Missing timeout argument for method '%s' can cause your program to hang indefinitely
W3101.description: Used when a method needs a 'timeout' parameter in order to avoid waiting for a long time. If no timeout is specified explicitly the default value is used. For example for 'requests' the program will never time out (i.e. hang indefinitely).

W0511.name: fixme
W0511.description: Used when a warning note as FIXME or XXX is detected.

W4701.name: modified-iterating-list
W4701.message: Iterated list '%s' is being modified inside for loop body, consider iterating through a copy of it instead.
W4701.description: Emitted when items are added or removed to a list being iterated through. Doing so can result in unexpected behaviour, that is why it is preferred to use a copy of the list.

W3301.name: nested-min-max
W3301.message: Do not use nested call of '%s'; it's possible to do '%s' instead
W3301.description: Nested calls ``min(1, min(2, 3))`` can be rewritten as ``min(1, 2, 3)``.

W2402.name: non-ascii-file-name
W2402.description: Under python 3.5, PEP 3131 allows non-ascii identifiers, but not non-ascii file names.Since Python 3.5, even though Python supports UTF-8 files, some editors or tools don't.

W0714.name: overlapping-except
W0714.description: Used when exceptions in handler overlap or are identical

W9005.name: multiple-constructor-doc
W9005.message: "%s" has constructor parameters documented in class and __init__
W9005.description: Please remove parameter declarations in the class or constructor.

W9006.name: missing-raises-doc
W9006.description: Please document exceptions for all raised exception types.

W9008.name: redundant-returns-doc
W9008.description: Please remove the return/rtype documentation from this method.

W9010.name: redundant-yields-doc
W9010.description: Please remove the yields documentation from this method.

W9011.name: missing-return-doc
W9011.description: Please add documentation about what this method returns.

W9012.name: missing-return-type-doc
W9012.description: Please document the type returned by this method.

W9013.name: missing-yield-doc
W9013.description: Please add documentation about what this generator yields.

W9014.name: missing-yield-type-doc
W9014.description: Please document the type yielded by this method.

W9015.name: missing-param-doc
W9015.description: Please add parameter declarations for all parameters.

W9016.name: missing-type-doc
W9016.description: Please add parameter type declarations for all parameters.

W9017.name: differing-param-doc
W9017.description: Please check parameter names in declarations.

W9018.name: differing-type-doc
W9018.description: Please check parameter names in type declarations.

W9019.name: useless-param-doc
W9019.description: Please remove the ignored parameter documentation.

W9020.name: useless-type-doc
W9020.description: Please remove the ignored parameter type documentation.

W9021.name: missing-any-param-doc
W9021.description: Please add parameter and/or type documentation.

W2901.name: redefined-loop-name
W2901.description: Used when a loop variable is overwritten in the loop body.

W1501.name: bad-open-mode
W1501.message: "%s" is not a valid mode for open.
W1501.description: Python supports: r, w, a[, x] modes with b, +, and U (only with r) options. See https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#open

W1502.name: boolean-datetime
W1502.message: Using datetime.time in a boolean context.
W1502.description: Using datetime.time in a boolean context can hide subtle bugs when the time they represent matches midnight UTC. This behaviour was fixed in Python 3.5. See https://bugs.python.org/issue13936 for reference.

W1503.name: redundant-unittest-assert
W1503.message: Redundant use of %s with constant value %r
W1503.description: The first argument of assertTrue and assertFalse is a condition. If a constant is passed as parameter, that condition will be always true. In this case a warning should be emitted.

W1506.name: bad-thread-instantiation
W1506.description: The warning is emitted when a threading.Thread class is instantiated without the target function being passed as a kwarg or as a second argument. By default, the first parameter is the group param, not the target param.

W1507.name: shallow-copy-environ
W1507.description: os.environ is not a dict object but proxy object, so shallow copy has still effects on original object. See https://bugs.python.org/issue15373 for reference.

W1508.name: invalid-envvar-default
W1508.message: %s default type is %s. Expected str or None.
W1508.description: Env manipulation functions return None or str values. Supplying anything different as a default may cause bugs. See https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.getenv.

W1509.name: subprocess-popen-preexec-fn
W1509.message: Using preexec_fn keyword which may be unsafe in the presence of threads
W1509.description: The preexec_fn parameter is not safe to use in the presence of threads in your application. The child process could deadlock before exec is called. If you must use it, keep it trivial! Minimize the number of libraries you call into. See https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#popen-constructor

W1510.name: subprocess-run-check
W1510.message: 'subprocess.run' used without explicitly defining the value for 'check'.
W1510.description: The ``check`` keyword  is set to False by default. It means the process launched by ``subprocess.run`` can exit with a non-zero exit code and fail silently. It's better to set it explicitly to make clear what the error-handling behavior is.

W1514.name: unspecified-encoding
W1514.message: Using open without explicitly specifying an encoding
W1514.description: It is better to specify an encoding when opening documents. Using the system default implicitly can create problems on other operating systems. See https://peps.python.org/pep-0597/

W1515.name: forgotten-debug-statement
W1515.message: Leaving functions creating breakpoints in production code is not recommended
W1515.description: Calls to breakpoint(), sys.breakpointhook() and pdb.set_trace() should be removed from code that is not actively being debugged.

W1518.name: method-cache-max-size-none
W1518.message: 'lru_cache(maxsize=None)' or 'cache' will keep all method args alive indefinitely, including 'self'
W1518.description: By decorating a method with lru_cache or cache the 'self' argument will be linked to the function and therefore never garbage collected. Unless your instance will never need to be garbage collected (singleton) it is recommended to refactor code to avoid this pattern or add a maxsize to the cache. The default value for maxsize is 128.

W4902.name: deprecated-method
W4902.description: The method is marked as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

W4903.name: deprecated-argument
W4903.description: The argument is marked as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

W4904.name: deprecated-class
W4904.description: The class is marked as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

W4905.name: deprecated-decorator
W4905.description: The decorator is marked as deprecated and will be removed in the future.

W1401.name: anomalous-backslash-in-string
W1401.message: Anomalous backslash in string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r prefix.
W1401.description: Used when a backslash is in a literal string but not as an escape.

W1402.name: anomalous-unicode-escape-in-string
W1402.message: Anomalous Unicode escape in byte string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r or u prefix.
W1402.description: Used when an escape like \u is encountered in a byte string where it has no effect.

W1404.name: implicit-str-concat
W1404.description: String literals are implicitly concatenated in a literal iterable definition : maybe a comma is missing ?

W1405.name: inconsistent-quotes
W1405.message: Quote delimiter %s is inconsistent with the rest of the file
W1405.description: Quote delimiters are not used consistently throughout a module (with allowances made for avoiding unnecessary escaping).

W1406.name: redundant-u-string-prefix
W1406.message: The u prefix for strings is no longer necessary in Python >=3.0
W1406.description: Used when we detect a string with a u prefix. These prefixes were necessary in Python 2 to indicate a string was Unicode, but since Python 3.0 strings are Unicode by default.

W1300.name: bad-format-string-key
W1300.message: Format string dictionary key should be a string, not %s
W1300.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary whose keys are not all strings.

W1301.name: unused-format-string-key
W1301.message: Unused key %r in format string dictionary
W1301.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that contains keys not required by the format string.

W1302.name: bad-format-string
W1302.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string is invalid.

W1303.name: missing-format-argument-key
W1303.message: Missing keyword argument %r for format string
W1303.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields doesn't receive one or more required keywords.

W1304.name: unused-format-string-argument
W1304.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields is used with an argument that is not required by the format string.

W1305.name: format-combined-specification
W1305.message: Format string contains both automatic field numbering and manual field specification
W1305.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string contains both automatic field numbering (e.g. '{}') and manual field specification (e.g. '{0}').

W1306.name: missing-format-attribute
W1306.message: Missing format attribute %r in format specifier %r
W1306.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses an attribute specifier ({0.length}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't have that attribute.

W1307.name: invalid-format-index
W1307.message: Using invalid lookup key %r in format specifier %r
W1307.description: Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses a lookup specifier ({a[1]}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't contain or doesn't have that key as an attribute.

W1308.name: duplicate-string-formatting-argument
W1308.message: Duplicate string formatting argument %r, consider passing as named argument
W1308.description: Used when we detect that a string formatting is repeating an argument instead of using named string arguments

W1309.name: f-string-without-interpolation
W1309.message: Using an f-string that does not have any interpolated variables
W1309.description: Used when we detect an f-string that does not use any interpolation variables, in which case it can be either a normal string or a bug in the code.

W1310.name: format-string-without-interpolation
W1310.message: Using formatting for a string that does not have any interpolated variables
W1310.description: Used when we detect a string that does not have any interpolation variables, in which case it can be either a normal string without formatting or a bug in the code.

W2101.name: useless-with-lock
W2101.message: '%s()' directly created in 'with' has no effect
W2101.description: Used when a new lock instance is created by using with statement which has no effect. Instead, an existing instance should be used to acquire lock.

W1113.name: keyword-arg-before-vararg
W1113.message: Keyword argument before variable positional arguments list in the definition of %s function
W1113.description: When defining a keyword argument before variable positional arguments, one can end up in having multiple values passed for the aforementioned parameter in case the method is called with keyword arguments.

W1114.name: arguments-out-of-order
W1114.message: Positional arguments appear to be out of order
W1114.description: Emitted  when the caller's argument names fully match the parameter names in the function signature but do not have the same order.

W1115.name: non-str-assignment-to-dunder-name
W1115.description: Emitted when a non-string value is assigned to __name__

W1116.name: isinstance-second-argument-not-valid-type
W1116.message: Second argument of isinstance is not a type
W1116.description: Emitted when the second argument of an isinstance call is not a type.

W1117.name: kwarg-superseded-by-positional-arg
W1117.message: %r will be included in %r since a positional-only parameter with this name already exists
W1117.description: Emitted when a function is called with a keyword argument that has the same name as a positional-only parameter and the function contains a keyword variadic parameter dict.

W6001.name: deprecated-typing-alias
W6001.description: Emitted when a deprecated typing alias is used.

W2301.name: unnecessary-ellipsis
W2301.description: Used when the ellipsis constant is encountered and can be avoided. A line of code consisting of an ellipsis is unnecessary if there is a docstring on the preceding line or if there is a statement in the same scope.

W2601.name: using-f-string-in-unsupported-version
W2601.message: F-strings are not supported by all versions included in the py-version setting
W2601.description: Used when the py-version set by the user is lower than 3.6 and pylint encounters an f-string.

W2602.name: using-final-decorator-in-unsupported-version
W2602.message: typing.final is not supported by all versions included in the py-version setting
W2602.description: Used when the py-version set by the user is lower than 3.8 and pylint encounters a ``typing.final`` decorator.

W0601.name: global-variable-undefined
W0601.message: Global variable %r undefined at the module level
W0601.description: Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but the variable is not defined in the module scope.

W0602.name: global-variable-not-assigned
W0602.message: Using global for %r but no assignment is done
W0602.description: When a variable defined in the global scope is modified in an inner scope, the 'global' keyword is required in the inner scope only if there is an assignment operation done in the inner scope.

W0603.name: global-statement
W0603.description: Used when you use the "global" statement to update a global variable. Pylint discourages its usage. That doesn't mean you cannot use it!

W0604.name: global-at-module-level
W0604.message: Using the global statement at the module level
W0604.description: Used when you use the "global" statement at the module level since it has no effect.

W0611.name: unused-import
W0611.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used.

W0612.name: unused-variable
W0612.description: Used when a variable is defined but not used.

W0613.name: unused-argument
W0613.description: Used when a function or method argument is not used.

W0614.name: unused-wildcard-import
W0614.message: Unused import(s) %s from wildcard import of %s
W0614.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used from a `'from X import *'` style import.

W0621.name: redefined-outer-name
W0621.description: Used when a variable's name hides a name defined in an outer scope or except handler.

W0622.name: redefined-builtin
W0622.description: Used when a variable or function override a built-in.

W0631.name: undefined-loop-variable
W0631.description: Used when a loop variable (i.e. defined by a for loop or a list comprehension or a generator expression) is used outside the loop.

W0632.name: unbalanced-tuple-unpacking
W0632.message: Possible unbalanced tuple unpacking with sequence %s: left side has %d label%s, right side has %d value%s
W0632.description: Used when there is an unbalanced tuple unpacking in assignment

W0640.name: cell-var-from-loop
W0640.description: A variable used in a closure is defined in a loop. This will result in all closures using the same value for the closed-over variable.

W0641.name: possibly-unused-variable
W0641.description: Used when a variable is defined but might not be used. The possibility comes from the fact that locals() might be used, which could consume or not the said variable

W0642.name: self-cls-assignment
W0642.description: Invalid assignment to self or cls in instance or class method respectively.

W0644.name: unbalanced-dict-unpacking
W0644.message: Possible unbalanced dict unpacking with %s: left side has %d label%s, right side has %d value%s
W0644.description: Used when there is an unbalanced dict unpacking in assignment or for loop

W0149.name: while-used
W0149.description: Unbounded `while` loops can often be rewritten as bounded `for` loops. Exceptions can be made for cases such as event loops, listeners, etc.

C0121.name: singleton-comparison
C0121.description: Used when an expression is compared to singleton values like True, False or None.

C0123.name: unidiomatic-typecheck
C0123.message: Use isinstance() rather than type() for a typecheck.
C0123.description: The idiomatic way to perform an explicit typecheck in Python is to use isinstance(x, Y) rather than type(x) == Y, type(x) is Y. Though there are unusual situations where these give different results.

C0112.name: empty-docstring
C0112.description: Used when a module, function, class or method has an empty docstring (it would be too easy ;).

C0114.name: missing-module-docstring
C0114.description: Used when a module has no docstring. Empty modules do not require a docstring.

C0115.name: missing-class-docstring
C0115.description: Used when a class has no docstring. Even an empty class must have a docstring.

C0116.name: missing-function-docstring
C0116.description: Used when a function or method has no docstring. Some special methods like __init__ do not require a docstring.

C0103.name: invalid-name
C0103.description: Used when the name doesn't conform to naming rules associated to its type (constant, variable, class...).

C0104.name: disallowed-name
C0104.description: Used when the name matches bad-names or bad-names-rgxs- (unauthorized names).

C0105.name: typevar-name-incorrect-variance
C0105.message: Type variable name does not reflect variance%s
C0105.description: Emitted when a TypeVar name doesn't reflect its type variance. According to PEP8, it is recommended to add suffixes '_co' and '_contra' to the variables used to declare covariant or contravariant behaviour respectively. Invariant (default) variables do not require a suffix. The message is also emitted when invariant variables do have a suffix.

C0131.name: typevar-double-variance
C0131.message: TypeVar cannot be both covariant and contravariant
C0131.description: Emitted when both the "covariant" and "contravariant" keyword arguments are set to "True" in a TypeVar.

C0132.name: typevar-name-mismatch
C0132.message: TypeVar name "%s" does not match assigned variable name "%s"
C0132.description: Emitted when a TypeVar is assigned to a variable that does not match its name argument.

C0202.name: bad-classmethod-argument
C0202.message: Class method %s should have %s as first argument
C0202.description: Used when a class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

C0203.name: bad-mcs-method-argument
C0203.message: Metaclass method %s should have %s as first argument
C0203.description: Used when a metaclass method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

C0204.name: bad-mcs-classmethod-argument
C0204.message: Metaclass class method %s should have %s as first argument
C0204.description: Used when a metaclass class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "mcs"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

C0205.name: single-string-used-for-slots
C0205.message: Class __slots__ should be a non-string iterable
C0205.description: Used when a class __slots__ is a simple string, rather than an iterable.

C2201.name: misplaced-comparison-constant
C2201.description: Used when the constant is placed on the left side of a comparison. It is usually clearer in intent to place it in the right hand side of the comparison.

C0501.name: consider-using-any-or-all
C0501.description: A for loop that checks for a condition and return a bool can be replaced with any or all.

C3401.name: dict-init-mutate
C3401.message: Declare all known key/values when initializing the dictionary.
C3401.description: Dictionaries can be initialized with a single statement using dictionary literal syntax.

C0198.name: bad-docstring-quotes
C0198.message: Bad docstring quotes in %s, expected """, given %s
C0198.description: Used when a docstring does not have triple double quotes.

C0199.name: docstring-first-line-empty
C0199.description: Used when a blank line is found at the beginning of a docstring.

C2701.name: import-private-name
C2701.description: Used when a private module or object prefixed with _ is imported. PEP8 guidance on Naming Conventions states that public attributes with leading underscores should be considered private.

C0410.name: multiple-imports
C0410.description: Used when import statement importing multiple modules is detected.

C0411.name: wrong-import-order
C0411.description: Used when PEP8 import order is not respected (standard imports first, then third-party libraries, then local imports).

C0412.name: ungrouped-imports
C0412.message: Imports from package %s are not grouped
C0412.description: Used when imports are not grouped by packages.

C0413.name: wrong-import-position
C0413.message: Import "%s" should be placed at the top of the module
C0413.description: Used when code and imports are mixed.

C0414.name: useless-import-alias
C0414.message: Import alias does not rename original package
C0414.description: Used when an import alias is same as original package, e.g., using import numpy as numpy instead of import numpy as np.

C0415.name: import-outside-toplevel
C0415.description: Used when an import statement is used anywhere other than the module toplevel. Move this import to the top of the file.

C0301.name: line-too-long
C0301.description: Used when a line is longer than a given number of characters.

C0302.name: too-many-lines
C0302.description: Used when a module has too many lines, reducing its readability.

C0303.name: trailing-whitespace
C0303.description: Used when there is whitespace between the end of a line and the newline.

C0304.name: missing-final-newline
C0304.description: Used when the last line in a file is missing a newline.

C0305.name: trailing-newlines
C0305.description: Used when there are trailing blank lines in a file.

C0321.name: multiple-statements
C0321.message: More than one statement on a single line
C0321.description: Used when more than on statement are found on the same line.

C0325.name: superfluous-parens
C0325.description: Used when a single item in parentheses follows an if, for, or other keyword.

C0327.name: mixed-line-endings
C0327.message: Mixed line endings LF and CRLF
C0327.description: Used when there are mixed (LF and CRLF) newline signs in a file.

C0328.name: unexpected-line-ending-format
C0328.message: Unexpected line ending format. There is '%s' while it should be '%s'.
C0328.description: Used when there is different newline than expected.

C3001.name: unnecessary-lambda-assignment
C3001.message: Lambda expression assigned to a variable. Define a function using the "def" keyword instead.
C3001.description: Used when a lambda expression is assigned to variable rather than defining a standard function with the "def" keyword.

C3002.name: unnecessary-direct-lambda-call
C3002.message: Lambda expression called directly. Execute the expression inline instead.
C3002.description: Used when a lambda expression is directly called rather than executing its contents inline.

C2401.name: non-ascii-name
C2401.message: %s name "%s" contains a non-ASCII character, consider renaming it.
C2401.description:
Used when the name contains at least one non-ASCII unicode character. See https://peps.python.org/pep-0672/#confusing-features for a background why this could be bad. 
If your programming guideline defines that you are programming in English, then there should be no need for non ASCII characters in Python Names. If not you can simply disable this check.

C2403.name: non-ascii-module-import
C2403.message: %s name "%s" contains a non-ASCII character, use an ASCII-only alias for import.
C2403.description:
Used when the name contains at least one non-ASCII unicode character. See https://peps.python.org/pep-0672/#confusing-features for a background why this could be bad. 
If your programming guideline defines that you are programming in English, then there should be no need for non ASCII characters in Python Names. If not you can simply disable this check.

C1802.name: use-implicit-booleaness-not-len
C1802.message: Do not use `len(SEQUENCE)` without comparison to determine if a sequence is empty
C1802.description: Empty sequences are considered false in a boolean context. You can either remove the call to 'len' (``if not x``) or compare the length against ascalar (``if len(x) > 1``).

C1803.name: use-implicit-booleaness-not-comparison
C1803.message: "%s" can be simplified to "%s", if it is strictly a sequence, as an empty %s is falsey
C1803.description: Empty sequences are considered false in a boolean context. Following this check blindly in weakly typed code base can create hard to debug issues. If the value can be something else that is falsey but not a sequence (for example ``None``, an empty string, or ``0``) the code will not be equivalent.

C1804.name: use-implicit-booleaness-not-comparison-to-string
C1804.message: "%s" can be simplified to "%s", if it is striclty a string, as an empty string is falsey
C1804.description: Empty string are considered false in a boolean context. Following this check blindly in weakly typed code base can create hard to debug issues. If the value can be something else that is falsey but not a string (for example ``None``, an empty sequence, or ``0``) the code will not be equivalent.

C1805.name: use-implicit-booleaness-not-comparison-to-zero
C1805.message: "%s" can be simplified to "%s", if it is strictly an int, as 0 is falsey
C1805.description: 0 is considered false in a boolean context. Following this check blindly in weakly typed code base can create hard to debug issues. If the value can be something else that is falsey but not an int (for example ``None``, an empty string, or an empty sequence) the code will not be equivalent.

C0200.name: consider-using-enumerate
C0200.message: Consider using enumerate instead of iterating with range and len
C0200.description: Emitted when code that iterates with range and len is encountered. Such code can be simplified by using the enumerate builtin.

C0201.name: consider-iterating-dictionary
C0201.message: Consider iterating the dictionary directly instead of calling .keys()
C0201.description: Emitted when the keys of a dictionary are iterated through the ``.keys()`` method or when ``.keys()`` is used for a membership check. It is enough to iterate through the dictionary itself, ``for key in dictionary``. For membership checks, ``if key in dictionary`` is faster.

C0206.name: consider-using-dict-items
C0206.description: Emitted when iterating over the keys of a dictionary and accessing the value by index lookup. Both the key and value can be accessed by iterating using the .items() method of the dictionary instead.

C0207.name: use-maxsplit-arg
C0207.description: Emitted when accessing only the first or last element of str.split(). The first and last element can be accessed by using str.split(sep, maxsplit=1)[0] or str.rsplit(sep, maxsplit=1)[-1] instead.

C0208.name: use-sequence-for-iteration
C0208.message: Use a sequence type when iterating over values
C0208.description: When iterating over values, sequence types (e.g., ``lists``, ``tuples``, ``ranges``) are more efficient than ``sets``.

C0209.name: consider-using-f-string
C0209.message: Formatting a regular string which could be an f-string
C0209.description: Used when we detect a string that is being formatted with format() or % which could potentially be an f-string. The use of f-strings is preferred. Requires Python 3.6 and ``py-version >= 3.6``.

C0113.name: unneeded-not
C0113.description: Used when a boolean expression contains an unneeded negation.

C0401.name: wrong-spelling-in-comment
C0401.message:
Wrong spelling of a word '%s' in a comment:
%s
%s
Did you mean: '%s'?
C0401.description: Used when a word in comment is not spelled correctly.

C0402.name: wrong-spelling-in-docstring
C0402.message:
Wrong spelling of a word '%s' in a docstring:
%s
%s
Did you mean: '%s'?
C0402.description: Used when a word in docstring is not spelled correctly.

C0403.name: invalid-characters-in-docstring
C0403.description: Used when a word in docstring cannot be checked by enchant.

C2503.name: bad-file-encoding
C2503.message: PEP8 recommends UTF-8 as encoding for Python files
C2503.description: PEP8 recommends UTF-8 default encoding for Python files. See https://peps.python.org/pep-0008/#source-file-encoding

C2801.name: unnecessary-dunder-call
C2801.description: Used when a dunder method is manually called instead of using the corresponding function/method/operator.

R0022.name: useless-option-value
R0022.description: Used when a value for an option that is now deleted from pylint is encountered.

R0123.name: literal-comparison
R0123.message: In '%s', use '%s' when comparing constant literals not '%s' ('%s')
R0123.description: Used when comparing an object to a literal, which is usually what you do not want to do, since you can compare to a different literal than what was expected altogether.

R0124.name: comparison-with-itself
R0124.description: Used when something is compared against itself.

R0133.name: comparison-of-constants
R0133.message: Comparison between constants: '%s %s %s' has a constant value
R0133.description: When two literals are compared with each other the result is a constant. Using the constant directly is both easier to read and more performant. Initializing 'True' and 'False' this way is not required since Python 2.3.

R0202.name: no-classmethod-decorator
R0202.message: Consider using a decorator instead of calling classmethod
R0202.description: Used when a class method is defined without using the decorator syntax.

R0203.name: no-staticmethod-decorator
R0203.message: Consider using a decorator instead of calling staticmethod
R0203.description: Used when a static method is defined without using the decorator syntax.

R0205.name: useless-object-inheritance
R0205.message: Class %r inherits from object, can be safely removed from bases in python3
R0205.description: Used when a class inherit from object, which under python3 is implicit, hence can be safely removed from bases.

R0206.name: property-with-parameters
R0206.message: Cannot have defined parameters for properties
R0206.description: Used when we detect that a property also has parameters, which are useless, given that properties cannot be called with additional arguments.

R6101.name: consider-using-namedtuple-or-dataclass
R6101.message: Consider using namedtuple or dataclass for dictionary values
R6101.description: Emitted when dictionary values can be replaced by namedtuples or dataclass instances.

R6102.name: consider-using-tuple
R6102.message: Consider using an in-place tuple instead of list
R6102.description: Only for style consistency! Emitted where an in-place defined ``list`` can be replaced by a ``tuple``. Due to optimizations by CPython, there is no performance benefit from it.

R6103.name: consider-using-assignment-expr
R6103.description: Emitted when an if assignment is directly followed by an if statement and both can be combined by using an assignment expression ``:=``. Requires Python 3.8 and ``py-version >= 3.8``.

R6104.name: consider-using-augmented-assign
R6104.message: Use '%s' to do an augmented assign directly
R6104.description:
Emitted when an assignment is referring to the object that it is assigning to. This can be changed to be an augmented assign.
Disabled by default!

R6105.name: prefer-typing-namedtuple
R6105.description:
'typing.NamedTuple' uses the well-known 'class' keyword with type-hints for readability (it's also faster as it avoids an internal exec call).
Disabled by default!

R5601.name: confusing-consecutive-elif
R5601.message: Consecutive elif with differing indentation level, consider creating a function to separate the inner elif
R5601.description: Used when an elif statement follows right after an indented block which itself ends with if or elif. It may not be ovious if the elif statement was willingly or mistakenly unindented. Extracting the indented if statement into a separate function might avoid confusion and prevent errors.

R3501.name: consider-refactoring-into-while-condition
R3501.message: Consider using 'while %s' instead of 'while %s:' an 'if', and a 'break'
R3501.description: Emitted when `while True:` loop is used and the first statement is a break condition. The ``if / break`` construct can be removed if the check is inverted and moved to the ``while`` statement.

R5501.name: else-if-used
R5501.message: Consider using "elif" instead of "else" then "if" to remove one indentation level
R5501.description: Used when an else statement is immediately followed by an if statement and does not contain statements that would be unrelated to it.

R2044.name: empty-comment
R2044.description: Used when a # symbol appears on a line not followed by an actual comment

R0401.name: cyclic-import
R0401.description: Used when a cyclic import between two or more modules is detected.

R0402.name: consider-using-from-import
R0402.description: Emitted when a submodule of a package is imported and aliased with the same name, e.g., instead of ``import concurrent.futures as futures`` use ``from concurrent import futures``.

R1260.name: too-complex
R1260.message: %s is too complex. The McCabe rating is %d
R1260.description: Used when a method or function is too complex based on McCabe Complexity Cyclomatic

R0901.name: too-many-ancestors
R0901.description: Used when class has too many parent classes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

R0902.name: too-many-instance-attributes
R0902.description: Used when class has too many instance attributes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

R0903.name: too-few-public-methods
R0903.description: Used when class has too few public methods, so be sure it's really worth it.

R0904.name: too-many-public-methods
R0904.description: Used when class has too many public methods, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

R0911.name: too-many-return-statements
R0911.description: Used when a function or method has too many return statement, making it hard to follow.

R0912.name: too-many-branches
R0912.description: Used when a function or method has too many branches, making it hard to follow.

R0913.name: too-many-arguments
R0913.description: Used when a function or method takes too many arguments.

R0914.name: too-many-locals
R0914.description: Used when a function or method has too many local variables.

R0915.name: too-many-statements
R0915.description: Used when a function or method has too many statements. You should then split it in smaller functions / methods.

R0916.name: too-many-boolean-expressions
R0916.message: Too many boolean expressions in if statement (%s/%s)
R0916.description: Used when an if statement contains too many boolean expressions.

R2004.name: magic-value-comparison
R2004.message: Consider using a named constant or an enum instead of '%s'.
R2004.description: Using named constants instead of magic values helps improve readability and maintainability of your code, try to avoid them in comparisons.

R0204.name: redefined-variable-type
R0204.description: Used when the type of a variable changes inside a method or a function.

R6301.name: no-self-use
R6301.description: Used when a method doesn't use its bound instance, and so could be written as a function.

R1701.name: consider-merging-isinstance
R1701.message: Consider merging these isinstance calls to isinstance(%s, (%s))
R1701.description: Used when multiple consecutive isinstance calls can be merged into one.

R1702.name: too-many-nested-blocks
R1702.description: Used when a function or a method has too many nested blocks. This makes the code less understandable and maintainable.

R1703.name: simplifiable-if-statement
R1703.message: The if statement can be replaced with %s
R1703.description: Used when an if statement can be replaced with 'bool(test)'.

R1704.name: redefined-argument-from-local
R1704.message: Redefining argument with the local name %r
R1704.description: Used when a local name is redefining an argument, which might suggest a potential error. This is taken in account only for a handful of name binding operations, such as for iteration, with statement assignment and exception handler assignment.

R1705.name: no-else-return
R1705.description: Used in order to highlight an unnecessary block of code following an if containing a return statement. As such, it will warn when it encounters an else following a chain of ifs, all of them containing a return statement.

R1706.name: consider-using-ternary
R1706.description: Used when one of known pre-python 2.5 ternary syntax is used.

R1707.name: trailing-comma-tuple
R1707.description: In Python, a tuple is actually created by the comma symbol, not by the parentheses. Unfortunately, one can actually create a tuple by misplacing a trailing comma, which can lead to potential weird bugs in your code. You should always use parentheses explicitly for creating a tuple.

R1708.name: stop-iteration-return
R1708.message: Do not raise StopIteration in generator, use return statement instead
R1708.description: According to PEP479, the raise of StopIteration to end the loop of a generator may lead to hard to find bugs. This PEP specify that raise StopIteration has to be replaced by a simple return statement

R1709.name: simplify-boolean-expression
R1709.message: Boolean expression may be simplified to %s
